title: Table 1: % Children enrolled in different types of schools. By age group and sex. 2024
description: Enrollment statistics for children in Meghalaya in 2024, categorized by age groups (6-14, 7-16, 7-10, 11-14, 15-16) and gender. The table compares enrollment percentages in Government, Private, and Other schools, as well as the percentage of children currently not in school.
data: | Age group and sex | Govt | Pvt | Other | Not in school | Total |

title: Table 2: % Children enrolled in different types of pre-schools and schools. By age. 2022
description: Detailed breakdown of educational enrollment for young children (ages 3 to 8) in Meghalaya for the year 2022. It distinguishes between various pre-school types (Anganwadi, Government pre-primary, Private LKG/UKG) and formal school types (Government, Private, Other), including data on children not attending any institution.
data: | Age | Pre-school | Pre-school | Pre-school | School | School | School | Not in pre-school or school | Total |
| Age | Angan-wadi | Govt pre-primary | Pvt LKG/UKG | Govt | Pvt | Other | Not in pre-school or school | Total |

title: Table 2: % Children enrolled in different types of pre-schools and schools. By age. 2022
description: Detailed breakdown of educational enrollment for young children (ages 3 to 8) in Meghalaya for the year 2022. It distinguishes between various pre-school types (Anganwadi, Government pre-primary, Private LKG/UKG) and formal school types (Government, Private, Other), including data on children not attending any institution.

title: Table 4: % Children by grade and reading level. All children. 2024
description: Assessment of foundational reading skills for children in Meghalaya in 2024, arranged by grade level (Standard I through VIII). The table categorizes students by their highest reading ability: Not even letter, Letter, Word, Standard I level text, or Standard II level text.
data: | Std | Not even letter | Letter | Word | Std I level text | Std II level text | Total |

title: Table 5: Trends over time
description: Longitudinal trends (2014, 2016, 2018, 2022, 2024) showing the percentage of Standard III children in Meghalaya capable of reading Standard II level text. The data is broken down by Government and Private schools.
data: | Year | % Children in Std III who can read Std II level text | % Children in Std III who can read Std II level text | % Children in Std III who can read Std II level text |

title: Table 6: Trends over time
description: Historical data (2014-2024) illustrating reading proficiency trends for Standard V and Standard VIII students in Meghalaya. The table displays the percentage of students in Government and Private schools who can read Standard II level text.
data: | Year | % Children in Std V who can read Std II level text | % Children in Std V who can read Std II level text | % Children in Std V who can read Std II level text | % Children in Std VIII who can read Std II level text | % Children in Std VIII who can read Std II level text | % Children in Std VIII who can read Std II level text |
| Year | Govt | Pvt | Govt & Pvt* | Govt | Pvt | Govt & Pvt* |

title: Table 7: % Children by grade and arithmetic level. All children. 2024
description: Assessment of foundational arithmetic skills for children in Meghalaya in 2024, arranged by grade level (Standard I through VIII). The table tracks proficiency levels including number recognition (1-9, 11-99), subtraction, and division.

title: Table 8: Trends over time
description: Longitudinal trends (2014-2024) showing the percentage of Standard III children in Meghalaya who can perform at least subtraction. The data is categorized by Government and Private schools.
data: | Year | % Children in Std III who can do at least subtraction | % Children in Std III who can do at least subtraction | % Children in Std III who can do at least subtraction |

title: Table 9: Trends over time
description: Historical trends (2014-2024) of arithmetic proficiency in Meghalaya, specifically measuring the percentage of Standard V and Standard VIII students who can perform division, compared across Government and Private schools.
data: | Year | % Children in Std V who can do division | % Children in Std V who can do division | % Children in Std V who can do division | % Children in Std VIII who can do division | % Children in Std VIII who can do division | % Children in Std VIII who can do division |

title: Table 10: Smartphone availability and use. By age. 2024
description: Digital access statistics for children aged 14, 15, and 16 in Meghalaya for 2024. The table covers smartphone availability at home, the ability to bring a phone for digital tasks, usability skills, and personal ownership of smartphones.

title: Table 11: Smartphone availability and use among 14-16-year-olds. By sex. 2024
description: Gender-based comparison of smartphone availability and usage for 14-16 year olds in Meghalaya (2024). It includes data on access at home, ability to use smartphones for digital tasks, and personal ownership rates for Boys vs Girls.

title: Table 15: Trends over time
description: Survey data showing the number of Primary and Upper Primary schools visited in Meghalaya during the years 2010, 2018, 2022, and 2024.

title: Table 16: Trends over time
description: Attendance trends in Meghalaya schools for the years 2010, 2018, 2022, and 2024. The table displays the average percentage of enrolled children present and the average percentage of teachers present.

title: Table 17: Trends over time
description: A longitudinal metric for 'All schools' in Meghalaya, tracking a specific percentage indicator across 2010, 2018, 2022, and 2024.

title: Table 18: Multigrade classes. 2024
description: Data on multigrade classroom observations in Meghalaya for 2024, specifically showing the percentage of schools where Standard I and Standard II children were observed sitting with other grades.
data: | % Schools | Std I children observed sitting with any other Std | Std II children observed sitting with any other Std |

title: Table 19: Observation of TLM (Teaching Learning Materials) in classrooms. 2024
description: 2024 observational data regarding the presence of Teaching Learning Materials (TLM) in Meghalaya classrooms (Std I and Std II) and whether student work was displayed.
data: | % Schools | TLM observed in classroom (apart from textbooks) | TLM observed in classroom (apart from textbooks) | Of those schools with TLM, work done by students displayed in classroom | Of those schools with TLM, work done by students displayed in classroom | Of those schools with TLM, work done by students displayed in classroom |

title: Table 20: Trends over time
description: Comprehensive school infrastructure and facility trends in Meghalaya (2010-2024). The table tracks the availability and status of mid-day meals, drinking water, toilets (including separate girls' toilets), libraries, electricity connections, and computers.
data: | Mid-day meal | Mid-day meal served in school on the day of visit | 51.9 | 47.9 | 49.1 | 61.5 |
| Mid-day meal | Kitchen/shed for cooking mid-day meal | 60.6 | 84.5 | 92.1 | 92.6 |
| Drinking water | No facility for drinking water | 70.6 | 76.1 | 74.4 | 65.6 |
| Drinking water | Facility but no drinking water available | 5.5 | 8.5 | 9.4 | 10.7 |
| Toilet | Facility but toilet not useable | 40.6 | 48.3 | 34.2 | 31.2 |
| Girls' toilet | No separate provision for girls' toilet | 64.8 | 37.3 | 44.7 | 46.7 |
| Girls' toilet | Separate provision but locked | 9.1 | 20.9 | 17.5 | 11.5 |
| Girls' toilet | Separate provision, unlocked but not useable | 11.4 | 11.9 | 7.9 | 10.7 |
| Girls' toilet | Separate provision, unlocked and useable | 14.8 | 29.9 | 29.8 | 31.2 |
| Library | Library but no books being used by children on the day of visit | 6.4 | 7.8 | 5.1 | 9.8 |
| Library | Library books being used by children on the day of visit | 15.6 | 2.8 | 11.1 | 17.2 |
| Electricity | Of schools with electricity connection, % schools with electricity available on the day of visit |  | 80.0 | 76.2 | 57.1 |
| Computer | No computer available for children to use | 97.3 | 97.9 | 98.3 | 96.7 |
| Computer | Computer available but not being used by children on the day of visit | 1.8 | 1.4 | 1.7 | 1.6 |
| Computer | Computer being used by children on the day of visit | 0.9 | 0.7 | 0.0 | 1.6 |

title: Table 21: Foundational Literacy and Numeracy (FLN) activities. 2024
description: Status of Foundational Literacy and Numeracy (FLN) implementation in Meghalaya schools for 2024 and the previous academic year. It covers government directives, online/offline teacher training, TLM receipt, funds receipt, and School Readiness Programs.
data: | % Schools | % Schools | Received a directive from govt to implement FLN activities with Std I-II/III | At least one teacher received training on FLN | At least one teacher received training on FLN | Received Teaching Learning Materials (TLM) for FLN activities** | Received funds for TLM for FLN activities** | School Readiness Programme held for Std l |
